titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Artillery-Election day. I took my son George with me to see the Procession, and to hear part of the Sermon, which was delivered by Mr: Baldwin— And again towards Evening I went with him on the Common, where the crowd was great. But the usual ceremonies were performed in Faneuil-Hall, the weather preventing the exhibition in open air. Though invited, I did not dine at the Hall— My principal object in declining was to save time; for which I am now very much press’d— My brother dined with us— John Smith went with him this afternoon to Quincy— My Sister and wife are both unwell with severe cold’s— Mrs: A’s cough has returned with violence, and is again very troublesome in the night— I wrote however more than usual this day, upon my lecture.

2. I attended a short time this morning in the Circuit Court of the Unites States, which commenced its Session here, yesterday— It is held by Judge Davis alone—Judge Cushing being from ill health unable to attend— John Smith, and my brother came into town early this morning— George returned to School at Mr: Webb’s the vacation having closed— I did not this day neglect my writing— Walk’d this Evening in the Mall.

3. After spending the day principally writing in my chamber, I walk’d in the Mall this Evening— It was the day of the weekly club, but not knowing where it met I did not attend— I was going to the Circuit Court, but was detained in the Common to see the exercises of the company stationed at Fort-Independence.— I finished the first sketch of my lecture 21.

4. My brother was again in town this morning; and returned this afternoon to Quincy.— I was a few minutes at the Circuit Court— Genl: Jackson called upon me this day, with two notes of Israel Thorndike, endorsed by David Sears, and William Prescott, with which he purposes to pay the Judgment of R. Bird’s Assignees against him— The notes are payable 1. August— But his payment to me, was to be the 6th: of this month— It being within 60 days his object was to get them discounted at the Banks— But he had applied yesterday at the Boston Bank, which had discounted nothing, and wished me to get them discounted at the United States Bank— I took them there accordingly; but they require that the person presenting a note should himself endorse it. And although the paper is perfectly good, and Mr: Cabot assured me that my name on the back of the Notes, would be a mere formality, I did not chuse to take upon myself that responsibility— I returned the Notes again to General Jackson, who will try them again to-morrow at the Boston Bank— And if they are not to be had, I shall be obliged to postpone the expectation of receiving the money, untill the 1st: of August.— I began upon my 22d: lecture.

5. Mr: Sears offered to present one of his notes for discount at the U.S. Bank, and the Boston Bank did this day discount the other; So that I have still a prospect of getting this transaction settled— This Evening there was a large party at Mr: Bartlett’s, which with John Smith and Caroline Johnson I attended— Neither Mrs: Smith nor Mrs: Adams were there.— The company was numerous, but the party dull as usual— Mr: & Mrs: Bartlett, are going next week to Amsterdam.—

6. I was at the Insurance-Office, but did not see General Jackson, and of course did not settle the demand against him, as it ought this day to have been— Without absolute deficiency of Industry, I have not this day, done so much at my professional duty as I ought—

7. The Summer came this day in some of its most vehement fervours— I heard Mr: Emerson both parts of the day— Mrs: Smith and her children went with us, and dined at Mr W. Smith’s.— It was the communion day— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 105. 106. and 107. and wrote the regular proportion of my lecture— Walk’d this Evening in the Mall, where there was a more numerous assemblage of people than I have seen there, since the year 1790.

8. I was great part of the morning engaged with Genl: Jackson in making the arrangements for the payment of his note which is to be completed to-morrow— Dr: Waterhouse dined with us.— Walking early this Evening in the Mall I met Mr: Söderström who is here for a few days upon a visit— On returning home I found Miss Dexter here; and also Mr: Jos: Hall— I executed with Mrs: Adams a Quit-Claim deed of the Lands which Mr: Jackson had conveyed to me, as security for the Judgment due to the Assignees of R. Bird; and Mr: Hall took the acknowledgment.

9. My Sister Smith went to spend a week with Mrs: S. A. Otis— I delivered to Genl: Jackson at Mr: Hall’s Office the Deed reconveying his lands— He gave me a check of the Boston Bank, and Mr: Sears a check on the U.S. Bank which together completed the payment due to R. Bird’s Assignees— I acknowledged satisfaction of the Judgment upon the record, and returned the original Note, which with the leave of the Court I had taken out— This afternoon I attended the anniversary celebration of the Humane Society, and heard Mr: Emerson at his own Church deliver a Discourse upon the subjects connected with that Institution— I lost much of my usual task of writing; but commenced the first draft of my 23d. Lecture having yesterday finished the 22d:— Walked some time this Evening in the Mall, where I met Mr: Marston— The weather last Night and all this day has been nearly at the highest summer heat.

10. I wrote to the Assignees of R. Bird, and sent them the certificate of the Cashier of the U.S. Bank for the balance of the money due them, which I yesterday received of Genl: Jackson, together with my account.— Dined with Mr: Otis and walk’d this Evening in the Mall— The weather continued very warm untill late this Evening when it began to moderate.

11. I received late this morning a letter, from Mr: C. Bulfinch, the chairman of the Select-men, requesting me to act with six other Gentlemen, as a Commissioner on the part of the town, to treat with the Boston Mill-Corporation respecting the filling up the Mill-Pond—and notice that the Commissioners were to meet at 4. O’Clock this afternoon at the Select-men’s chamber in Faneuil-Hall.— I was obliged in propriety to go to Cambridge this afternoon— I went immediately, and informed Judge Davis and Mr: John Joy, who are two of the Commissioners that I could not attend this Evening. Judge Davis was also obliged to go to Cambridge, and we concluded to meet to-morrow afternoon. I dined early and immediately after dinner, walked to Cambridge, and attended the installation of Mr: John Farrar, as Hollis Professor of Mathematics and experimental Philosophy.— The performances were as customary— But the new Professor’s discourse was in Latin— The Governor and Lieutt: Governor with many members of the Council and Senate were there; but scarcely any other Company— After the Ceremonies were over, I called for a few minutes at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and then walk’d home. I found Mrs: Adams was at Mrs: S. A. Otis’s; where I went and pass’d the remainder of the Evening.

Health and Illness

div.p: 12. I walk’d to Cambridge this Morning—J. Smith went with me— Called at Dr: Waterhouse’s; and at 10 O’Clock delivered my 17th: lecture— It was the dryest and dullest that I have ever given; and I look forward with much anxiety to those which are to succeed— I afterwards attended Dr: Waterhouse’s lecture, which was upon the primary matter— Dined at his house, after calling on President Webber, who was gone into Boston— At 2. O’Clock attended the Declamation, which was indifferent— I returned to Boston in the Stage, and met the Town’s Commissioners Judge Davis—W. Parsons, John Joy, Tristram Bernard, William Brown, and Redford Webster, at the Selectmen’s chamber— After some explanations from Mr: Bulfinch, and some examination of the Papers, Judge Davis was appointed Chairman and Mr: Webster Secretary, a vote was pass’d to notify the Secretary of the Mill Corporation of our powers, and that we were ready to treat with them, and should meet again, next Monday, at 4. in the afternoon— We then adjourned— Coming home I met Dr: Morse, and afterwards President Webber, who informed me of the issue of a debate in the board of Overseers to modify a vote of the Corporation respecting the readmission of Students dismissed from the College in consequence of the late disturbances there.— The proposed modification was rejected— A motion also in the Senate for a Legislative enquiry into the State, and affairs of the College, was this day negatived by a single vote— The Governor had an epileptic fit this day, at the board of Overseers in the midst of the debate— They immediately adjourned; and he attended again in the afternoon. On returning home I found Mrs: Adams very unwell, with a sick head ache—and she continued ill untill late at Night.

13. In walking to Cambridge yesterday, and the day before, I blistered the sole of one of my feet so much, that I was confined to the house this day, untill the Evening, when I walk’d about an hour in the Mall. I employed my time to some purpose by commencing the fair copy of my 18th: lecture; for I have now run through the Stock, I had prepared last Winter, at Washington— These lectures are indeed precisely the labour of Sisyphus; a fortnight of close application scarcely prepares me for the performance of half-an-hour.— I received a letter from Mr: Boyd, respecting his intention to remove to the western Territory— Weather so cold, we were obliged to keep a fire— My Sister was here, part of the morning.

14. Heard at Mr: Emerson’s this whole day, Mr: Norton, the young man whom I heard about two months since at Quincy— He does not appear to have improved his pronunciation— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 108, 109, and 110.— All, with the two preceding them, upon the subject of regeneration— I also wrote something upon my lecture— Caroline pass’d the Evening at Mrs: S. A. Otis’s; where I called to return with her home— J. Smith went out to Quincy this morning.

15. Devoted all the morning, and the afternoon untill 4. O’Clock to the composition of my lectures— At 4. I went to Faneuil-Hall, and met the other Commissioners of the Town, respecting the Mill-Pond— Mr: Otis and Mr: Peck at one time, and Mr: W. H. Sumner with Mr: Welsh at another appeared, and made certain propositions on the Part of the Mill Corporation— The Commissioners sat debating upon them and discussing a variety of proposals untill near 9 O’Clock. We finally agreed upon sundry propositions on our part to be made to them at their meeting, which is to be next week, and we adjourned to the 29th: at 4. P.M— We came very near adjourning without agreeing upon any thing; for the want of specific propositions— This is the great source of delay upon deliberations, where there is no special stimulus to act. When I came home I found Mr: S. A. Otis with his family, Miss Dexter and Miss Boardman at my house at tea— And they spent the Evening with us.

16. John Smith returned from Quincy, and brought our youngest boy John, with him— He has been there upwards of three weeks. Mr: W. Sawyer called upon me, to request letters of Introduction to Mr: Pinckney in London, and to Mr: Armstrong in Paris; which I promised him— Spent the whole day in the closest application to my lecture— Evening with Caroline Johnson, and John Smith at Mrs: Sumner’s; where there was assembled a numerous company of ladies and gentlemen. It was late before we came home.

17. Two servants left us, which throws again a weight of domestic occupation upon me— I called at the Boston Bank, to make some arrangement respecting my note to I. P. Davis, which will be due next week, and for which I must make some provision— My Sister Smith and her daughter returned from Mrs: Otis’s.— I finished the fair copy of my 18th: and began my 19th: lecture— I now labour with much more assiduity than success.

18. Went to the Fire and Marine Insurance Office, to transfer five of my shares to Mr: Chapman the Cashier of the Boston Bank, as security for a note which I meant to offer for discount there next Monday; but finding they are about reimbursing to their Stockholders the third part of their Capital to which they are authorized by the Legislature, there will be no occasion for me to make the transfer— I wrote by Captn: Beale, immediately to my father— I was unable to write so much upon my lecture as I wished—

div.p: 19. Walked to Cambridge, and at 10. O’Clock, read my 19th: Lecture— It was the dullest I have yet delivered, and my only resource was to read it over as fast as possible— Though as long as any of those which have taken me from 40 minutes to three quarters of an hour, I went through it in 32 minutes— Attended immediately afterwards Dr: Waterhouse’s Lecture; which was on the process of generation in plants and the egg— Spent an hour in the library, dined at the Drs: and attended at 2. the declamation, which was indifferent— Immediately afterwards I walk’d home— Wrote very little at my lecture; but employed the remnant of the afternoon reading.

20. I was again employed from home so great a part of the day, that my professional labours were much interrupted— My brother and his wife came into town, and dined with us— They returned at Night to Quincy. My Sister and her children also went out this afternoon.

21. Heard Mr: Pearce of Brookline the whole day— Took the Children with me, and Caroline Johnson went in the afternoon. The remainder of the day I employed upon my lecture, and in reading Tillotson’s Sermons 111. and 112. No part of my time was lost— In the Evening, I walked with the children in the Mall.

22. I called this forenoon at the Fire and Marine Insurance Office, and received the Certificates of the new Shares, and the repayment of the portion of Capital authorized by the Legislature.— I then paid at the Boston Bank my small note to I. P. Davis, being fortunately not obliged to renew any part of it.— At 6 in the afternoon I attended a meeting of the Commissioners on the Town’s business, where we reviewed some of our proceedings at the last meeting; and adjourned to Monday next—4. P.M.— Judge Davis and Captain Bernard, were absent— I afterwards called upon Captain Bernard Mr: W. Sargent at Mr: Murray’s, and obtained from him such information as I could respecting Mr: Boyd’s enquiries.

23. I intended to have written this day to Mr: Boyd, was I was so steadily employed the whole day upon my fair copy of my 20th: lecture, which I this day began— For this Lecture I can make scarcely any use at all of my first draught— This makes my present labour the more toilsome— I also lost some time in translating Martial’s Epigram, about the digressions of lawyers.

24. Employed this day as yesterday, excepting that I endeavoured to find out the club, this Evening— I enquired of Judge Davis who informed me it would be at Dr: Warren’s— I called there in the Evening, but he was gone out of town, and I was referred to Mr: Cobb’s— I also went there, and he too was out of town— Upon which I gave up the pursuit, and returned home.— My lecture studies are now at once painful and unsatisfactory.

25. Steady rain through the whole day, which confined me wholly to the house— I was engaged very assiduously, in reading and writing for my lecture— And still found not time for writing to Mr: Boyd.— Fires— Mr: Foster’s visit.

div.p: 26. I wrote this morning to Mr: Boyd— John Smith came in from Quincy— Went to Cambridge to attend my lecture; and returned to Quincy at Night. I walk’d to and from Cambridge— Delivered my 19th: Lecture— I was apprehensive for its success; but it was less tedious than that of the last week— Immediately after I attended Dr: Waterhouse’s Lecture; which was upon the System of Botany by Linnaeus; with a biographical sketch of his character. After passing an hour in the Library, I dined at the Doctor’s, and at 2. O’Clock attended the Declamation— The Sophomore class this day commence their performances in public— I found the warmth of the weather on my return home very oppressive, though we yesterday had fires.

27. I called this morning to return Mr: Foster’s visit, but did not find him. Mr: Quincy had invited me to dine with him in the Country, with the agricultural Society, but I am so confined by my official duties that I could not bestow the time, and excused myself. I remained at home however to no great purpose. Read more than I wrote.

28. Heard Mr: Willard, the younger, in the forenoon, and Mr: Emerson in the afternoon. In the Evening I took a ride with Mrs: Adams and the children to Jamaica-Plains.— Read Tillotson’s Sermon 113. but failed of time for the next. I barely finished my 20th: Lecture, leaving the subject to be continued in the next.

29. At 12. There was a meeting of the Trustees of the Hopkins donation, which I attended— The annual meeting in May, had failed, by the Death of the Treasurer, Mr: Storer, who was accustomed to call them. The purpose of this meeting was to choose a new member, and a Treasurer in his stead— Mr: Jonn: Jackson was elected for both— I dined at Judge Dawes’s—in company with several of the members— At 4. in the afternoon, attended a meeting of the town-Commissioners on the Mill-pond.— We were engaged untill 7. in receiving a proposal as formal, upon which we had acted before; and confirming our former votes.— After returning home I went in pursuit of George, and bathed with him at the alms-house wharf— John was again quite unwell— Having been so great a part of the day absent from home, I wrote but little— Began however, upon the last copy of my Lecture 21.

30. The principal part of this day I was employed upon my Lecture, and repaired the deficiency of yesterday’s writing. I was however at the Offices, about noon, and first heard of an occurrence of a very gloomy complexion— A new outrage from a British armed ship, and the disgrace of one of our own frigates— Walk in the Evening with George— And called upon Mr: E. Gray, and Dr: Howard, to inform them the Club would meet to-morrow at my house.

Day. During the month which is now expiring, I have been able to employ more of my time to useful purpose than I could in those which preceded it— My family has enjoyed tolerable health; and my Nights have been little interrupted— I rise however, not with much regularity, between 5 and 8— Read 4. Chapters of the Bible— Hear George read as many pages of Dufief’s Grammar— Breakfast— Work at my Lectures untill 12 or 1. Walk to State-Street, and after half an hour spent there, return home to dinner— Afternoon employed again in writing untill dark— Walk an hour in the Mall— Sup— Bed, between 10 and 11— On Friday’s I spend the day at Cambridge, and can do little else.
